Signed-off-by: Johannes Ott <info@johannes-ott.net>

Merge branch '2.5.x' of https://github.com/DerOetzi/openhab-addons into 2.5.x

timeline.bodyHTML:
Suggested change
AlertMode alertMode1 = state1.getAlertMode();
AlertMode alertMode2 = state2.getAlertMode();
return ((alertMode1 == null && alertMode2 == null) || (alertMode1 != null && alertMode1.equals(alertMode2)))
return Objects.equals(state1.getAlertMode(), state2.getAlertMode())
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: This is a good point. I already thought about this and in my opinion it would be more Java-Standardconform to implement an equals method inside the state class and replace the calls of this isEqual(state1, state2) by state1.equals(state2)
replies.author: DerOetzi

replies.bodyText: I have refactored the State class by adding the equals method. There is one change to previous isEqual method at HueBridgeHandler used before. The attribute float[] xy of State Class was not compared in isEqual() method and is now compared by equals method. As I think there is no affect because of this logic change, but perhaps someone of you can verify this.
replies.author: DerOetzi

timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.body: Java has a standard contract for equals/hashcode that two equal objects must have the same hashcode. So just generate a hashcode method for this class and I think we can call this PR done.
timeline.bodyText: Java has a standard contract for equals/hashcode that two equal objects must have the same hashcode. So just generate a hashcode method for this class and I think we can call this PR done.

timeline.body: One last thing, can you run this class through the formatter. It looks like the generated single-line if statements don't have brackets.

replies.bodyText: I have used the formatter settings in Visual Studio Code as described on openhab documentation. It doesn't add brackets automatically.
replies.author: DerOetzi

replies.bodyText: I added the brackets manually, now.
replies.author: DerOetzi

replies.bodyText: It doesn't? Strange, that means that the VSC formatter settings is different from the Eclipse one. The Eclipse one is the standard so looks like the VSC formatter needs to be changed.
replies.author: cpmeister

timeline.message:
